entry.title: SAP Ariba Sourcing & Contracts 2511 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
SAP Ariba Contracts - Feature highlights

AI Copilot Joule in SAP Ariba Contracts (SCONTR-1279)

Joule, SAP's generative AI copilot, is now available in SAP Ariba Contracts. Joule uses a conversational interface to help users complete tasks efficiently.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Supplier Eligibility Validation in Contract Workspaces (SCONTR-1445)

This feature enables buyers to set supplier eligibility criteria using supplier registration and qualification statuses from SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance. It ensures that only suppliers who meet the specified eligibility criteria are included in a contract. These criteria can be validated during various stages, such as during contract creation, publication, or when transferring contract data and line items to integrated external systems like SAP ERP.

View implementation details and more here.

 

 

SAP Ariba Sourcing - Feature highlights

Ability to Block Access to Classic Sourcing for Project or Event Creation

(PSOURCE-1452)

This feature blocks product sourcing users from creating sourcing projects and requests in the classic SAP Ariba Sourcing interface. To create sourcing projects or events, users can use the guided sourcing interface, which streamlines the process and helps users complete more projects with less effort.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Add Plants to Material Line Items in Hybrid Mode

(PSOURCE-1468)

This feature allows you to associate a plant with material line items (not associated with any BOMs) in hybrid mode within product sourcing. This improves the creation of Purchase Info Records (PIRs) by automatically collecting prices for material line items in product sourcing.

Business End User Tasks

Creating a Purchase Info Record from a Material Line Item Linked to a Plant

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Upload CSV File to Autofill Term Values for Material Quote Events in Product Sourcing

(SOURCE-1641)

 

This feature provides system administrators an interface to upload a CSV file that includes predefined term values. These values are used to autofill term values when a new material quote event is created in product sourcing.

Previously, the system prefilled term values in a material quote event only from matching terms in the most recently awarded event. As a result, users had to enter term values manually for every new material quote event.

Now, the system prefills term values from a CSV file uploaded by the system administrator. When a new material quote event is created, the system reuses term values based on the following values:

  • TermID

  • TermName

  • MaterialID

  • SAPPlantID

  • SAPSupplierID

This feature is supported for Approved Manufacturer List (AML) suppliers only.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Add, Update, Remove URLs in Guided Sourcing Full Projects

(SOURCE-2542)

 

With this feature, project owners can add, update, and delete URLs in the Events and other documents section of a guided sourcing full project.

The option to add URLs is added under Create > Document in the Events and other documents section in guided sourcing full projects.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

View implementation details and more here.

 

Exclude Reverted Savings Allocations in Analytical Reports in Guided Sourcing

(SOURCE-2559)

This feature ensures that when draft savings allocations are reverted to the published state, the draft allocations are discarded. Consequently, only active (non-reverted) allocations are included in analytical reports generated from savings forms in guided sourcing full projects.

Previously, analytical reports generated from savings forms in guided sourcing full projects included all savings allocations, including those reverted from drafts. With this feature, these reports now only include active (non-reverted) savings allocations.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Export All Rows from Content Tables in Guided Sourcing Events

(SOURCE-2590)

 

This feature enables buyer users to export the complete set of rows from content tables within guided sourcing events.

Changes to the User Interface

  • The Export all rows option is added to the download icon () for the following event pages in guided sourcing:

    • The Monitor page: In the Items that needs quotes and the Questions, requirements, and attachments tables

    • The Award page: In the Award allocation and Questions, requirements, and attachments tables

View implementation details and more here.

 

Additional Contract Workspace Types in Guided Sourcing Full Projects

(SOURCE-2595)

 

This feature adds additional contract workspace document type options to guided sourcing full projects.

Currently, in the Events and other documents section of guided souring full projects, you can create a Contract workspace document as only the Procurement type. This feature adds the following additional Contract workspace document types:

  • Sales

  • Internal

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Import and Export Event Content in XLSX Format in Sourcing

(SOURCE-2596)

This feature enables buyers to import and export event content in SAP Ariba Sourcing in the XLSX format.

Previously, event content could only be exported and imported in the XLS format. With this feature, both XLS and XLSX formats are supported. While XLSX is set as the default export format, you can still opt for XLS based on your preference.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Communication Support in SAP Business Network Discovery Postings for Sourcing Events 

(SOURCE-2640)

This feature enables communication between buyers and suppliers in SAP Business Network Discovery postings for sourcing events. Buyers can directly respond to supplier-initiated questions, send messages to suppliers, and receive responses within the event posting.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Automatic Initial Offer Submissions in Guided Sourcing 

(SOURCE-2647)

 

This feature adds the ability to copy participants and bids from a past event to a new event and use the past bids as initial bid submissions in the new event.

Previously in guided sourcing, buyer users needed to use a multi-round event to reuse bids as initial bids for subsequent rounds. Users couldn't copy bids from a past single event to a new single event. Now, buyer users can copy participants and items with their associated bids from past single events and reuse the bids as initial bids in a new single event.

For the buyer, this feature ensures that supplier bids remain unchanged between events, without the need for a multi-round event. This also gives suppliers the option to not login and interface with the event unless they want to modify their bid, which saves time for the supplier.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Generate Event Summary in Guided Sourcing Using Generative AI (SOURCE-2670)

 

This feature enables buyer users to generate event summary in guided sourcing utilizing generative AI capabilities.

The summary is generated using the following data from the sourcing event: ID,Title,Description,Type,Base Language,Currency,Owner,Display Version,Contract Months,Contract Effective Date,Contract Expiration Date,Baseline Spend,Target Saving Percentage,Create Date,Last Modified,Origin,Template, and Supplier Bids.

The summary is generated in the event's base language, not the user's locale. It is created at the event level, so all users can see the same summary. If a user chooses to regenerate the summary, it is based on the data visible to that user, not the overall event data.

Note: This premium feature is available at no cost during the trial period.

View implementation details and more here.

 

View Predecessor Projects in Analytical Reports in Guided Sourcing 

(SOURCE-2694)

 

This feature enables you to view predecessor project details in analytical reports for sourcing requests, events, and full projects in guided sourcing.

Previously, predecessor project details were not included in analytical reports for sourcing requests, events, and full projects in guided sourcing. With this feature, you can now add the Predecessor Project column on the Pivot Layout page of the report wizard when creating an analytical report. Once added, these details will appear in the Predecessor Project column in reports. However, data from projects originally created using the classic SAP Ariba Sourcing interface will appear in the Based on Project column instead of the new Predecessor Project column.

Changes to the User Interface

On the Pivot Layout page of the analytical report wizard, a new field, Predecessor Project, is added for sourcing requests, events, and full projects in guided sourcing.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Access Controls for Task Comments 

(SOURCE-2716)

 

This feature adds access controls for task comments in guided sourcing full projects.

You can now specify which user groups can access task comments in a guided sourcing full project. Only users with the specified access permissions, or the Project Owner, can see an access controlled comment. Project Owners can view all task comments. Access controls are chosen below the comment. Comments that do not use access controls are visible to all project members.

Changes to the User Interface

Task detail pages now include Access control options below the the comment field. Click the button on the right side of the Access control field to choose options.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Ability to Make Counter-offers in Guided Sourcing Events 

(SSINDUSTRY-517)

This feature enables buyers to propose counteroffers to suppliers during a new round of a sourcing event. A counteroffer is a special type of negotiation round in multi-round bidding, giving buyers an additional way to secure competitive pricing from suppliers.

Previously, buyers could not propose a take-it-or-leave-it offer to suppliers.

With this enhancement, buyers can do the following:

  • Set a specific price as a counteroffer in a new round.

  • Share the counteroffer with selected suppliers.

Supplier can respond to the counter offer in the following manner:

  • If suppliers accept, the counteroffer price is recorded as their submitted quote for that line item. Buyers can then either proceed to awarding or start another negotiation round.

  • If there is no response from suppliers, their previously submitted quote remains valid and continues in the event.

View implementation details and more here.

Author: Allan Soo

Introduction

Healthcare public sector procurement spend is among the largest across the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). In 2021, 31.9% of all public procurement spend touches on public healthcare and infrastructure [1]. Nearly 75% of public spend on healthcare came from taxpayers [2]. With an ageing population and a shrinking taxpayer base, governments across the world are grappling with these fiscal challenges. One solution is to deploy effective spend management, procurement solutions across cost-intensive sectors of the economy to keep costs down.

Figure depicting the percentage government expenditure across the OECD-EU countries for 2023 [3]. Public sector procurement across the OECD-EU markets was 14.7% (2023), an increase of 0.9% compared to 2019.  

Why an effective, public procurement platform is crucial for public healthcare and governments?

Public procurement in healthcare is one of the most regulated forms of purchasing dealing with hospitals, pharmacies, and qualified suppliers. This requires complex compliance to purchasing pharmaceutical ingredients, chemicals and other regulated products to be compliant to public healthcare agencies. An example is the procurement of surgical implants and tools which must comply with the Therapeutic Goods Association (TGA) and other dangerous goods regulations.

Healthcare public procurement is becoming a significant challenge for governments worldwide due to factors such as an ageing population, rising deficits and total debts, the high costs of running healthcare facilities, and increased health and safety regulations.

Track spend and compliance across cost-intensive healthcare segments by different categories with SAP Ariba Category Management, SAP Ariba Intake Management and SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle Performance Management

SAP Ariba Category Management gives public sector healthcare purchasers the tools to track spend goals on their most cost-intensive areas of their agency including high-tech equipment, specialized hospital beds, pharmaceutical purchases and more.

The solution gives public healthcare purchasers the option to manage supplier performance and track these against budgets, manage funds and investments assigned and set to them by the government.

The solution also offers customers a 360-degree visibility into the supplier’s healthcare certifications and qualifications, making sure that they comply to directives and maximize compliance across all purchases made for the public facilities. For example, Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) license for Australia, Wholesale Distribution Authorisation for EU suppliers supplying medicinal products, and Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency certification for medicinal product manufacturing in the United Kingdom.

Adverse events can then be monitored using SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance Management to manage supplier risks appropriately. 3rd party data such as D&B can give government buyers additional intelligence on the market risk of that supplier such as sustainability, supply chain exposure, and aid in calculating inherent and residual risk scoring…and so on. Up to 25 custom risk scores can be applied to the healthcare supplier in SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

Renegotiate and manage multiple quotes across healthcare suppliers to drive cost savings with finance

To keep costs down, buyers have the ability with SAP Ariba Sourcing and Procurement for Public Sector in SAP S/4HANA, to manage different quotes and renegotiate prices with existing suppliers to obtain better deals. For example, evaluating the procurement of multiple MRI and X-ray machines, and different existing drug prices to encourage better competition between pharmaceutical suppliers to drive down prices.

Buyers can take advantage of the SAP Taulia Private Cloud solution with SAP S/4HANA and Dynamic Discounting feature where fast, early account payable transactions towards suppliers can lead to discounted cash savings that yield improved bottom line benefits for public healthcare finance customers.

Connect SAP Ariba Sourcing and SAP Ariba Buying solutions to the SAP S/4HANA ERP for high-level spend management and monitoring

Go beyond purchasing and ordering with high-level dashboard spend visibility [4] to track the list of purchase orders with SAP Ariba Central Procurement with SAP Ariba Buying (3EN) and SAP Ariba Buying, with guided buying capabilities (2NV) into SAP S/4HANA. Easily track the process flow of your purchases and export accounting documents to SAP finance and accounting solutions. Use three-way matching against invoice, purchase order and goods receipt to ensure that cost information is accurate. Request quotes from suppliers, allocate budget and discuss on pricing terms.

One highly relevant area for this is the operational procurement of medical apparel, protective equipment, gloves and face masks. You as the buyer want the tools to negotiate with suppliers on favorable pricing terms, sort price lists in Catalogs available over the SAP Business Network, and see the list of purchase orders, invoices and goods receipts in one place. You can set estimated budgets throughout the quotation process and track how far below under the target price you are able to get the costs down to attain cost savings.

Figure showing SAP Ariba Buying and Invoicing solution where healthcare purchasers can track how far below taxpayer funded budget they can obtain when purchasing medical supplies like gloves.

With these solutions, healthcare public sector buyers and public finance can move away from matching for accuracies and scrutinize cost details on these items and work collaboratively with other departments to find alternative suppliers and products that offer cheaper and better-quality substitutes.  

Leverage AI solutions for contracts management

SAP Ariba Contract Intelligence by Icertis SolEx has contract authoring capabilities that are bolstered by AI to automate much of the clause generation that is in line with the public healthcare industry and to drive compliance. Examples can include authoring in sustainability criteria, medical manufacturing license requirements from suppliers, and assigning responsibilities on direct suppliers and their affiliates. By automating the contract lifecycle, lead times can be reduced and anomalies within contract clauses can be detected and flagged for risk mitigation. The solution helps users identify contract leakage risks to prevent cost blowouts and put boundaries on spend conditions for public healthcare purchases. Risk scores on suppliers can be imported from SAP Ariba Supplier Risk to SAP Ariba Contracts to guide contract awarding decisions so that risk-aware awarding decisions can be made. Managing suppliers is part of the public sector procurement responsibility to ensure that government healthcare agencies continue receiving the best outcomes for the budget they are given with the right contracts in place.

Put cost guardrails on healthcare goods and services procured

With WK value contracts [5] in SAP S/4HANA, SAP Ariba Contracts [6] users can set guardrails against overspending on suppliers. Given that in healthcare settings the quantity of goods can be non-negotiable, SAP Ariba Contracts offers the flexibility to adjust quantity (through quantity contracts) and assign other attributes such as discounts on purchased goods through supplier collaboration and negotiations. Buyers can set cost parameters on the value contracts and publish it through the Cloud Integration Gateway to SAP S/4HANA. Purchase cost data can then be ingested by finance solutions to monitor and act on the financial performance of the health agency.

Smart Peppol invoicing with SAP S/4HANA and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management

With eInvoicing solutions offered with SAP Documents and Reporting Compliance (cloud edition) within S/4HANA ERP Public Cloud Edition, SAP Business Network via SAP Integration Suite, and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management - Peppol compliant documents can be exchanged to help government healthcare sectors align with eInvoicing compliance requirements or eliminate the use of physical paper. Eliminating physical paperwork and complying to Peppol eInvoicing means enhancing fraud-prevention systems in place to build trust with the public and install financial protections, improves productivity and minimizes errors in costing amounts.  Peppol is used by over 40 countries worldwide for business-to-government transactions, and is becoming a standardized, secure method of receiving invoices from the private sector supplier base by government agencies. Public hospitals and other healthcare agencies can examine and analyze invoice costs based on the high-fidelity information supplied electronically within the system, making it easily auditable for finance.

AI-driven Statement of Work (SOW) creations in SAP Fieldglass to alleviate workloads and focus on the things that matter

Minimize admin work and hire contractors to help comply to a variety of laws during the SOW creation process. Use the GenAI solution at SAP to identify opportunities to control costs during the SOW creation and reduce document creation times by about 71% by inputting titles, summaries and extracting data from PDF documents. With freed-up workloads, users can focus on the quality, risk and service traits of the contract (such as proper skills matching for best labour productivity outcomes). An example includes SOW creation for biohazardous health waste disposal services and scoping the boundaries of work, and clearly stating what services are in and out of scope and using SOW teams feature to collaborate with non-procurement colleagues on budget planning with finance that addresses high-spend service categories.

Improved SOW rates negotiation and cost management features on contracted services

Service buyers can negotiate for better rates post-agreement, automate offboarding signatures to cease spend, ensure hours worked are fulfilled by the contractors, reallocation of unspent SOW funds back to master SOW, inactivate cost centers when they are no longer used, and trigger alerts when rates vary away from agreed ones. These are features that are offered by SAP Fieldglass to service buyers in public healthcare settings to put a lid on costs.

Picture this, you need to onboard technicians to provide maintenance and calibration services for the complex equipment that the hospital has. Your rates need to be specified clearly, and any pay deviations need to be notified to the service buyer, clear start-end dates for the services and so on need to be in the SOW for legal reasons. You use the GenAI feature to produce an SOW quickly, double check the contents of this document, and have the work order issued. Skills are clearly specified for the job to minimize lead times onsite, and the best labour-hire is made. Therefore, costs are controlled, and the best productivity is obtained for maintenance work at the hospital.

Support green procurement practices

SAP Ariba Sourcing integrates with the suite of SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP sustainability solutions to drive green procurement practices across the public healthcare sector. Given that Scope 3 contributes to around 79% of total carbon emissions [7] for this sector across the OECD markets, governments can use SAP tools to drive sustainable procurement practices on their direct suppliers. Examples including procuring gloves with a low product carbon footprint, high recycled content, and rubber data to ensure that illegal deforestation has not contributed to its production.

Alongside SAP Ariba Supplier Management, SAP Fieldglass and SAP Ariba Contracts, public healthcare sectors can manage risk appropriately and enforce sustainability practices and compliance on suppliers and contractors. This includes due diligence screening solutions on a supplier’s human rights and deforestation records, having the right sustainability credentials, and embedding sustainability due diligence into the core operational and strategic sourcing processes from procurement to the ERP environment. Given the mandates that governments must meet for their own net-zero, human rights and material circularity directives - SAP Ariba, SAP Fieldglass and SAP ERP Sustainability solutions provide a comprehensive suite of products to drive decarbonization and compliance in the public healthcare space. Partner solutions on the SAP app store can be used to enrich supplier data with sustainability scores and other external intel.

Tap into the SAP Spend Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud solution for rich data reporting on procurement spend

Enrich healthcare spend data with other SAP Business Data Cloud products to gain deeper insights into the entire healthcare organization’s finance and spend data. SAP Spend Intelligence offers customers a large variety of data products it can ingest. For example, sustainability, risk, contract leakages and off-contract purchase order spend.  By providing strategic and operational insights into a public healthcare’s spend, buyers can optimize for and eliminate out non-compliance and uses AI and machine learning to automatically allocate spend categories neatly for interpretation. SAP Joule can be employed to clean and present cluttered data in a meaningful way that helps drive high-level decision-making processes which maximizes healthcare spend impacts and cuts down maverick and unwanted tail spend.

Conclusion

SAP Ariba, SAP Fieldglass and SAP S/4HANA ERP solutions provide finance and spend management solutions that offer customers the tools to keep up to date with the latest innovations in driving cost savings, optimize spend, manage down risks, reduce fraud and work collaboratively with public sector finance teams in government. Given the significance of public healthcare sectors across developed markets, innovative procurement spend management solutions play a key role in controlling costs in a high-expenditure industry. For years to come, healthcare expenses are projected to increase with an ageing population, rising deficits and living cost challenges.

This requires a comprehensive, suite of solutions for the public sector that leverages best-of-breed AI and solution offerings that advance the modernization of public sector procurement and finance operations. Governments have a responsibility to foster trust, comply to own directives, address fiscal challenges across the economy for the wellbeing of citizens, and deliver services cost-effectively to the public.

entry.title: Understanding the Purpose of the Predecessor ProjectField in SAP Ariba
entry.content:
In SAP Ariba, the Predecessor Project field is designed to help users create logical, traceable, and organized relationships between projects. Although users often assume the predecessor feature is intended for copying data, its primary purpose is to build project relationships that support reporting, visibility, and structured project hierarchies.

This article explains what the Predecessor Project field is used for, how it differs from the Copy from Project capability, and why predecessor projects remain selectable even after they are completed or approved.

What Is the Purpose of the Predecessor Project Field?

The Predecessor Project field serves two main purposes:

  1. Establishing a Link Between Related Projects

Selecting a predecessor project allows you to link the current project to an existing one.

  • This relationship does not require copying values from the predecessor.
  • If the sole intention is to copy data, users should instead use the Copy from Project option.
  • The predecessor linkage provides context, relationships, and traceability between projects.

2.   Supporting Hierarchical Reporting (Subprojects)

When you assign a predecessor project, the system can treat the current project as a follow-on or subproject in reporting views.

  • This helps teams and organizations visualize chains of related initiatives.
  • It ensures reporting structures reflect how projects truly relate to one another.

Predecessor Project vs. Copy from Project

Although both functions may prepopulate fields, they serve different purposes.

Predecessor Project

  • Selecting a predecessor from the dropdown menu creates a follow-on relationship.
  • Fields that exist in both the predecessor and the current project may be pre-populated.
  • The main goal is linking projects, not cloning them.
  • The predecessor project retains its identity and lifecycle.

Copy from Project

  • Creates a copy of an existing project.
  • The copied project retains most of the original project’s attributes.
  • You cannot select a new template or project type when copying.
    • The new project inherits the project type and uses the latest published version of the template originally used.
  • This option is intended for reusing structure and content—not linking projects.

Why Is a Predecessor Project Still Available After Completion or Approval?

A predecessor project remains selectable even after it is completed, approved, or closed, because its function is not tied to its status. The predecessor mechanism exists to maintain continuity and logical connections across related initiatives, regardless of where each project is in its lifecycle.

The purpose of a predecessor is not to transfer or copy data—it is to maintain a conceptual and reporting link.

Example Scenario: ABC Corporate Electronics Procurement

Consider the following use case:

  • ABC  manager creates a parent RFI project to collect information from suppliers.
  • Once the RFI is completed, each team member creates their own individual sourcing or contracting project to procure electronic devices based on their personal needs.
  • Even though the original RFI project is already completed, it remains available as a predecessor.
  • Each team member sets the RFI project as their predecessor, creating a clear traceable line between the parent project and all the follow-on projects.

This ensures:

  • All child projects remain connected to the original sourcing initiative.
  • Reporting and audits reflect a complete project hierarchy.
  • Stakeholders can easily understand the sequence and relationship between efforts.

How Field Copying Behaviors Are Controlled in SAP Ariba (Advanced Field Configuration)

Whether fields are copied, synced, or inherited across projects (including predecessor and copied projects) depends on Advanced Field Configuration settings. These settings determine when and how field values flow between parent, predecessor, or copied projects.

Below are the key configuration options:

  • Sync in copied project on create:
    • This option copies fields when using the Copy from Contract field on create or Actions > Copy Project.
  • Sync in follow-on project on create:
    • This option copies fields when using the Actions > Follow-on Project or by selecting a Predecessor Project.
  • Sync in subagreement on create:
    • This option copies fields when using the Parent Agreement field on create or Actions > Sub Agreement.
  • Sync in subproject on create:
    • This option copies fields when using the Actions > Create Subproject (from the Documents tab).
  • Sync in subproject on change:
    • Makes the field in a subproject be auto pulled from its parent project whenever the field is updated in the parent project, including when the subproject is created.
  1. These options are not available for all fields and must be configured by an SAP resource.
  2. Present under Advanced tab of Field Configuration for specific fields.

 

Summary

Feature

Predecessor Project

Copy from Project

Purpose

Link projects logically

Reuse content by creating a copy

Effect

Creates follow-on relationship; may prefill shared fields

Creates a new project based on another

Template control

Uses template of the current project

Inherits template of the original project

Best used for

Reporting structure, traceability, subproject relationships

Cloning project design, structure, and content
